Tuesday evening, Senator Frank
Church outlined a three point "end
the war" resolution that he claims
will satisfy hawks and doves alike.

for complete withdrawal of all
American forces, and a ban on
invasions of Lao-, Cambodia and
North Vietnam.
Church stated that this policy
would help the United States come
out of the Indochina war with the
people of this country united.
"Passage of such a joint resolution
would go far toward avoiding, in
the aftermath of Viet Nam, another
epidemic of Joe McCarthyism like
that which poisoned the country
after the Korean war," said
Church.

which Church and fellow senator
John Sherman Cooper plan to put
before Congress in the coming

French learned before us, the

Church.

general. The ex-newscaster held

up their minds."

significant it should be reported,

they are in the Soviet Union."

myself, looking across the freshman playing field from my stone

dorms. I sat quietly for a moment,
watching the sun set behind the
strange tree-tops of Dunning Park,
perhaps the most beautiful sight on
campus. "...Or a powerhouse."

Locke used to put up a "DANGERHIGH VOLTAGE" sign every now

of mystery to the little building
with the big green beams.
"Going to the astronomy hut
tonight, Les?"
It was Doug. I nodded happily,
jumped down and started my
evening trek across the field to the
tiny observatory. Doug didn't want
to come. Actually, few people ever
really want to come. They can't see
what one stands to gain from
pointing a black tube here and
there, looking at a few stars that
one might not ordinarily see, and
Pointing it again. What can I tell
them? That they are living on a
speck of dust, that a person should
bat least be aware of the far
grander things going on in places
he can not reach? Not a very
convincing argument. It sends
most of my friends running for the
snack bar or the television set.
Where in Space Are We?
I opened the door, groped for the
light, and stood in admiration of the

ancient instrument. Brass screws,
gears and clock drive shining from
the tall, black pedestal gives it the
air of an old Tom Thumb, and I
never fail to amaze. After
unlocking the shutters I began to
roll the roof back by hand, when it
struck me that although I was
wearing only an undershirt, I was
warm enough. No thermal underwear or sweaters or winter
coats. No gallons of hot coffee or
hopelessly fogged lenses. No icicles
dropping from the oak tree tonight.
It's finally spring? The thaw has
come, the pier is solid on the pole.
And tonight shall be a winner.
I pulled down the big refractor
and chose two long-focal length
eyepieces from the eyepiece box.
Although a nine and one half inch
object glass makes the refractor
my favorite telescope, there are
others better suited to observe
particular objects, or just to look
about casually through our planet's
window. The very‘spotting scope
attached to the larger refractor is
itself a fairly decent three inch
refractor, and a tempermental
eight inch reflector sat in one
corner until it was finally carted
down to Rowland Hall for repairs.
A four inch reflector, Dr. Walker's
own antique, stands at wobbly
attention near a jumble of equally
ancient brass tubes and wheels, the
remains of a transit circle. There is
also a Questar, but this is not kept
in the observatory until it is to be
used.

in the Big Dipper, the well-known
"exploding galaxy". I had barely
adjusted my eyes when the door
started rattling. I made believe it
was a dog, at least until it asked to
be let in. In walked Judy, an enthusiastic student in Dr. Walker's
Wednesday night astronomy class.
"God, it's Wednesday!" I thought.
I closed up the star charts that
littered the floor, put away my own
hppes for the night, and awaited
the flood. Before long about thirty
young and middle-aged people had
crowded themselves into the little
house.
Judy: Wednesday
"Where's Dr. Walker?" asked at
least four in unison. When I told
them that he wasn't going to be
there tonight, the disappointment
of thirty tired people settled to the
ground like a heavy fog. One man
headed for the door, but I had been
careful to lock it for that very
reason. It stalled him long enough
for me to check the allignment on
M82 and M81 (a companion spiral

Great Globular Cluster

success. We stood before great
clusters of stars and galaxies, stars
of red and greeen and lavender.

may not have seen anything but a
few white dots in the eternal
Baltimore haze, a good many were
able to pick up and study the faint
streaks and blobs that were all we
could see of galaxies of billions of
stars. At the end of the night, the
three who still remained saw the
Great Globular Cluster in Hercules, M13. "Now that," explained

Being a casual starwatcher in
Baltimore requires considerable
imagination. Most of the galaxies
and distant clusters are very dim,
some fading irretrievably into
smoggy oblivion. But in spite of

enough curiosity to keep alive a
small Hopkins Astronomy Club,
meeting every other Wednesday
night at seven-thirty in Rowland
300 (this Wednesday is a meeting).

itself a remarkable showing for

oak tree is more than welcome to
stop in and introduce him or herself. You might be lucky enough to
see one of the more impressive
nebulae or double stars. In any
event, you will soon find the instrument to be more of a mirror
than a telescope. A quick glimpse
at where you aren't in this
universe, and you begin to wonder.

The Stein family—a fairy tale come true
By RICHARD GURLITZ
Once upon a time (the early part
of this century), there were four
Americans who lived in Paris.
They lived at 27 rue de Fleurus, and
just around the corner too.
Their names were Gertrude, Lee,
Michael, and Sarah Stein. They
collected strange pictures. Little
did they know that the strange
pictures that they knew and loved
so much at 27 rue de Fleurus would
become one of the finest collections
of modern art the world has ever
known.
They collected pictures painted
by their friends Henri (Matisse),
Pablo (Picasso), Juan (Gris),
Paul (Cezanne), and many others.
It was a good thing that the four
Americans did this, because at that
time other picture collectors didn't
like those strange pictures.
All Good Things
After many years and good times
at the 27 rue de Fleurus apartment
the Steins moved away and their
collection of strange pictures was

broken up and sent to all corners of
the world. The pictures were very
sad about this because they had
developed a very close friendship
among themselves.
Soon, nobody remembered just
which pictures had been together in
the apartment. (The pictures did
but they couldn't tell anybody.) But
luckily Gertrude had taken a
photograph of the 27 rue de Fleurus
apartment. All the pictures were in
the photograph.
Last year, the Museum of
Modern Art found the photograph
and planned a reunion for all the
pictures in it. They gathered the
paintings by Picasso, Cezanne,
Matisse, Gris, Renoir and their
friends, to make an exhibition.
First the exhibition stayed in
New York, hut then it came to
Baltimore. It is going to stay in
Baltimore until June 13.
A Bridge
Art historians consider this
reunion very important because it
acts as a bridge between the art of

the past century and that of the
present. The paintings of Renoir
show the last phases of Impressionism while those by
Cezanne and Matisse usher in the
Modern Movement.
Gertrude collected the early
works of Picasso including some
from his cubist paintings, his blue
period and his rose period.
A model of the house created by
le Corbusier (a modern French
architect) for Michael and Sarah
Stein also travels with the exhibit.
No Machinery
In the early part of this century
many artists were concerned with
the stagnation that Impressionism
and Neo-Classicism brought. The
break that they made from this was
at first turned down by the critics.
The change coming around in
thought and society was not dealt
with by the old-timers. The
machine had come to dominate
culture but only a few of the Im-

pressionists recognized this.
Dominating the machine and
renouncing eclecticism became the
byword of the modern movement.
The Steins with their interest in
this new art were in large part
responsible for the early success of
the modern movement,as borne out
in the present exhibition at the
Baltimore Museum of Art.

Once upon a time (the early part
of this century), there were four

by their friends Henri (Matisse),

It was a good thing that the four
Americans did this, because at that
time other picture collectors didn't
like those strange pictures.
All Good Things
After many years and good times
at the 27 rue de Fleurus apartment
the Steins moved away and their
collection of strange pictures was

broken up and sent to all corners of
the world. The pictures were very
sad about this because they had
developed a very close friendship
among themselves.
Soon, nobody remembered just
which pictures had been together in
the apartment. (The pictures did
but they couldn't tell anybody.) But
luckily Gertrude had taken a
photograph of the 27 rue de Fleurus
apartment. All the pictures were in
the photograph.
Last year, the Museum of
Modern Art found the photograph
and planned a reunion for all the
pictures in it. They gathered the
paintings by Picasso, Cezanne,
Matisse, Gris, Renoir and their
friends, to make an exhibition.
First the exhibition stayed in
New York, hut then it came to
Baltimore. It is going to stay in
Baltimore until June 13.
A Bridge
Art historians consider this
reunion very important because it
acts as a bridge between the art of

the past century and that of the
present. The paintings of Renoir
show the last phases of Impressionism while those by
Cezanne and Matisse usher in the
Modern Movement.
Gertrude collected the early
works of Picasso including some
from his cubist paintings, his blue
period and his rose period.
A model of the house created by
le Corbusier (a modern French
architect) for Michael and Sarah
Stein also travels with the exhibit.
No Machinery
In the early part of this century
many artists were concerned with
the stagnation that Impressionism
and Neo-Classicism brought. The
break that they made from this was
at first turned down by the critics.
The change coming around in
thought and society was not dealt
with by the old-timers. The
machine had come to dominate
culture but only a few of the Im-

pressionists recognized this.
Dominating the machine and
renouncing eclecticism became the
byword of the modern movement.
The Steins with their interest in
this new art were in large part
responsible for the early success of
the modern movement,as borne out
in the present exhibition at the
Baltimore Museum of Art.
